abstract.text: Wrapper for autolayout manipulation.
Do not instantiate this directly. Use “layout” on a
view query to get this.
Iterate the rows in the current grid(s) with an arbitrary
data array, passing the data item and row (i.e. quadrant/guide)
to a closure. Number of rows created == length of data array.
Use the closure to create the hierarchy within the quadrant.
Data type can correspond to ConstructibleWithData if desired
so that items can be created in the closure using the data.
Optionally iterate rows
This specialized method allows you to provide the type and
optional id of the top-level items you created in the
closure and have these returned as a new query of those
top-level items (of the specified type/id).
Query from the current items using a closure specifying
the maximum number of items the query should return.
Returns empty if current query has no items.
Example: myAutoLayout.with(3) { $0.buttons }
NOTE: the query returned from the closure must contain
compatible AutoLayout types, including UIView and Guide
Show relative positions over top of queried item(s).
For example: topLeading, center, etc.
Query from the current items using a closure
and return the first item found.
Example: myAutoLayout.withFirstOf { $0.buttons }
See also “with(max)” to return specific number of items.
NOTE: the query returned from the closure must contain
compatible AutoLayout types, including UIView and Guide
Assign “axis” to the queried stack view(s).
This affects the axis along which the arranged views are laid out.
Iterate the cells in the queried grid(s) with an arbitrary
data array, passing the data item and cell (i.e. quadrant/guide)
to a closure. Number of cells created == length of data array.
Use the closure to create the hierarchy within the quadrant.
Data type can correspond to ConstructibleWithData if desired
so that items can be created in the closure using the data.
Optional sort directions (8 in total) support diverse
flow progressions, for example
to progress
down the cells of the first column, and then to the next
column, etc. Default is
Respects layout direction, unless specified to
PERFORMANCE: Grids with a large number of cells may cause
performance issues due to the number of guides/constraints involved.
Make sure to performance test (e.g. via Instruments) when using this API.
For complex cell arrangements or multi-cell quadrants see also “make”.
Enter debug mode.
This provides both visual typographic debugging
and console debugging.
See debugTypographic() for more options.
QueryInterface provides the common interface to
queried items via Query, Mutator and Autolayout wrappers.
Present the queried Presentable item(s) and
automatically dismiss them after a delay
with optional dismiss speed, presentation
speed/delay, and completion handler.
Provide a non-optional array of data models
(applied in parallel to items) to be used
in presentation.
Completion handler is passed a query
of each item to take action on.
Embed this query of view(s) in a SwiftUI hierarchy
and use the closure to apply SwiftUI modifiers.
Example:
Turn on visual and console debugging, with options.
Turn off console debugging.
QuerySelectionInterface represents any wrapper (Query,
Mutator or AutoLayout) that can select/deselect queried items.
Create new views, layers, guides or nodes using a trailing closure.
These (child) items can be added to the (parent)
view(s) of the current query via in($0).
The return type will be Guide (child guides of the parent views).
Follow this call by further mutations applicable to the new guides.
Alternatively, to control the return type, use the generic method.
ItemQueryInterface represents any wrapper that can
access the underlying items and act on them via closure
in a way that does not alter the original query.
Query, Mutator and AutoLayout all support this,
as does AnyMutator.
Display the entire layer hierarchy in the console.
Provide option “includeAll” to see C3 internal types
and other private types in the output.

inlineContent.text: This works on debug builds only. It’s used for debugging only.

closure within which you can create the hierarchy.

top-level items (of the specified type/id).
Create new views, layers, guides or nodes using a trailing closure.
These (child) items can be added to the (parent)
view(s) of the current query via in($0).
The return type will be CALayer (child layers of the parent views).
Follow this call by further mutations applicable to the new layers.
Alternatively, to control the return type, use the generic method.
Iterate the cells in the current grid(s) with an arbitrary
data array, passing the data item and cell (i.e. quadrant/guide)
to a closure. Number of cells created == length of data array.
Use the closure to create the hierarchy within the quadrant.
Data type can correspond to ConstructibleWithData if desired
so that items can be created in the closure using the data.
Optional sort directions (8 in total) support diverse
flow progressions, for example
to progress
down the cells of the first column, and then to the next
column, etc. Default is

closure and have these returned as a new query of those
top-level items (of the specified type/id).
PERFORMANCE: Grids with a large number of cells may cause
performance issues due to the number of guides/constraints involved.
Make sure to performance test (e.g. via Instruments) when using this API.
Add a debug label with optional title.
Detach queried items from their super items and return those
items in the query (which you can either use by reattaching,
or just let the query go out of scope and the items to deallocate).
NOTE: Detaching views will also remove associated constraints.
Enable interaction between Backdrop(s) and a delegate.
For example, if tapping the backdrop(s) means something.
Any
that can work with references.

Iterate the columns in the current grid(s) with an arbitrary
data array, passing the data item and column (i.e. quadrant/guide)
to a closure. Number of columns created == length of data array.
Use the closure to create the hierarchy within the quadrant.
Data type can correspond to ConstructibleWithData if desired
so that items can be created in the closure using the data.
Optionally iterate columns
Respects layout direction, unless specified to
This specialized method allows you to provide the type and
optional id of the top-level items you created in the
closure and have these returned as a new query of those
top-level items (of the specified type/id).
Prevent the item(s) from dismissing on tapping Backdrop.
(Default behavior is to dismiss on tapping Backdrop
and run any provided action closures.)
Iterate all the columns in the current grid(s) passing the
index (+ position) and the column (quadrant) to the provided
closure within which you can create the hierarchy.
Optionally iterate columns
Respects layout direction, unless specified to
Return
(or
) from the closure to
continue iterating,
(or
) to stop iterating,
to skip
column positions before
resuming or
to skip to
column position
and resume at that point. Indices will remain consecutive
regardless of column position.
This specialized method allows you to provide the type and
optional id of the top-level items you created in the
closure and have these returned as a new query of those
top-level items (of the specified type/id).
Save the current query to an external variable.
For this to work with view controller properties
create a property as an “empty” query/mutator of the
correct type, then save anywhere in the chain, e.g.:
var shape = Query<View,Shape>.empty()
or  var shape = Q
.empty()
Shape().in($0)….save(&shape)
This operator supports saving not only the results
of the query but any other state, like references, etc.
Randomly iterate the cells in the current grid(s) with an arbitrary
data array, passing the data item and row (i.e. quadrant/guide)
to a closure. Number of cells created == length of data array.
Use the closure to create the hierarchy within the quadrant.
For example, given a grid of 10 cells and a data array of 4 items
there will be 4 cells created at random locations in the grid.
Data type can correspond to ConstructibleWithData if desired
so that items can be created in the closure using the data.
Conditional method to turn console debugging on
if there is an existing (passed) debug wrapper (with options).
Display the entire layout guide hierarchy in the console.
Provide option “includeAll” to see C3 internal types
and other private types in the output.

inlineContent.text: This works on debug builds only. It’s used for debugging only.

view(s) of the current query via in($0).
The return type will be UIView (child views of the parent views).
Follow this call by further mutations applicable to child views.
Alternatively, to control the return type, use the generic method.
Support conditional inline logic in chainable interfaces.
Add action to be executed when Backdrop is tapped on.
SPECIAL BEHAVIOR: If a CancelButton exists within the
hierarchy of the current item(s) and that button has
it’s own attached action, that action will also be
run when the backdrop is tapped (assuming Backdrop
dismissal has not been disabled).
NOTE: it’s not necessary to dismiss the item(s) from
within the closure, dismissal is automatic – unless
disabled via “backdropTapDoesNotDismiss()”.
Associate dependent sibling item(s) with a master item.
Detaching the master item will detach the dependent siblings.
Iterate all the cells in the current grid(s) passing
an index (+ cell position) and the cell (quadrant)
to the closure within which you can create the hierarchy.
Optional sort directions (8 in total) support diverse
flow progressions, for example
to progress
down the cells of the first column, and then to the next
column, etc. Default is

Apply a theme to the elements of this alert.
In most cases you can simply apply the theme at
the point of attachment (e.g. Alert().in(.. with:theme))
however in case the elements use attributed strings
(e.g. letter spacing, hyphenation, etc) then you
must apply the theme after the elements have
had their text applied (i.e. using this method).
CAVEAT: This will not apply the theme to hidden elements
or title/text elements that do not have text content.
Keep this in mind in case you want to reveal those
elements later – you would need to apply the theme
manually at that point.
As an alternative to using this method append the
“apply()” method within each callback.
Prepare the item(s) for presentation.
This is the state
presentation
(typically when the item is not visible to the user).
It is also used in the defult dismiss() to
reverse the process.
NOTE: prepare() is called automatically by the
system when the item is attached to the hierarchy.
If calling it manually, you must ensure it is safe
to call multiple times.
Add query of items to the current query. Will succeed
if the added query items are of the same type/subtype.
Will add items onlyif not exists (union) preserving order.
Set constant for a specific attribute and optional priority
on the queried views.
Optionally, specify
to find constraints where
the current items match the second item (
) in the
constraint or either items (
TIP: for most autolayout needs use the AutoLayout operators such
as size, width, height, center, pin, etc, which both set the
initial constraint(s) and, if the constraint is already set,
update the constant value. Reserve this method for more advanced layout.
Present the queried Presentable item(s) and
automatically dismiss them after a delay
with optional dismiss speed, presentation
speed/delay, and completion handler.
Completion handler is passed a query
of each item to take action on.

For example: A1, C3, etc

Protocol to wrap the ability to create/save wrappers
separate from their declarative chains.
Additional specialized operators that apply specifically to AutoLayout
Turn on visual typographic debugging.
Provide
(dark or light), whether to
include typographic
information and
which typographic
to include
(e.g. .firstXHeight, etc).
Display the entire view hierarchy in the console.
Provide option “includeAll” to see C3 internal types
and other private types in the output.

inlineContent.text: This works on debug builds only. It’s used for debugging only.

abstract.text: Associate dependent sibling item(s) of the current query
in parallel with the master item(s) of another query.
Detaching the master item(s) will detach the
dependent sibling item(s).
Perform auto layout changes with options or parameters within
a closure without affecting the outer mutator.
Treat the current query’s base and item type to match
a given Builder closure type. Beware: this may remove
the base and/or items altogether if the current query
cannot be successfully cast to the builder type.
Update the items with the related model objects
either initially or whenever the model changes.
Provided model array is applied in parallel to items.
Optionally provide whether the visual appearance
should be updated always, conditionally or never.
For non-view based queries (layers, guides, nodes)
get the containing (or owning) view(s).
Constrain the item(s) on a specific attribute
using the AutoConstraint DSL from within a closure.
Update debug label. This method is TBD.
Traverse this query’s items and another query’s items in
parallel, with zipper returning a new autolayout wrapper for each.
For base item, will resolve to the base item of the last
iteration OR by passing reevaluateBase:true to the common
super item of all items.
Dismiss the queried Presentable item(s)
with optional duration, delay and completion
handler that the “present()” implementation
can choose to work with.
Completion handler is passed this query
of each item to take action on.
Query from the current items using a closure.
Returns empty if current query has no items.
Example: myAutoLayout.with { $0.buttons }
NOTE: the query returned from the closure must contain
compatible AutoLayout types, including UIView and Guide
Turn on console debugging with options.
Modify and provide action for confirmation of this Alert,
applying modifications to a ConfirmButton.
Be sure to pass the application Theme when attaching dialog via
“in(with:theme)” so that the confirm button will obtain the correct theme.
It’s not necessary to size this text to fit, as autolayout
will do that for you.
NOTE: if confirmation is required, it is mandatory to implement
this method with at least an action determining what to do
on confirmation. Unlike the cancel button, this method does
automatically support dismissal of the dialog, unless a confirm
action is provided, in which case the dialog will automatically
dismiss on tap.
To hide confirm button, provide $0.hidden(true) to the callback.
Select items of a certain type and act
on them in a closure without affecting
the outer query.
Create new views or guides using a trailing closure.
These (child) items can be added to the (parent)
item(s) of the current query via in($0).
The return type will be from the last AutoLayout chain returned.
Follow this call by further mutations applicable to the new items.
Protocol to support any wrapper that can
do simple chaining (return self) or chaining
of items that remain the same T type.
Create new views, layers, guides or nodes using a trailing closure.
These (child) items can be added to the (parent)
view(s) of the current query via in($0).
The return type wil be the generic type specified (e.g. Label.self).
Follow this call by further mutations applicable to the new items.
Get the parent UIView(s) of the current view(s).
See also Query.parent() which supports getting
– e.g. query.parent(Guide.self)
Using the queried items, apply a transform to each creating
a query of new items. If these items do not yet exist in the
item hierarchy attach() can be used to add them.
Traverse this query’s items and another query’s items
in parallel, returning the original query that has
as many items as the shortest query of the two.
Wrapper for autolayout manipulation.
Do not instantiate this directly. Use “layout” on a
view query to get this.
Modify and provide action for cancellation of this Alert as
necessary, applying modifications to a CancelButton.
Be sure to pass the application/ Theme when attaching dialog via
“in(with:theme)” so that the cancel button will obtain the correct theme.
It’s not necessary to size this text to fit, as autolayout
will do that for you.
It’s not necessary to dismiss the dialog via action as this
is automatic behavior with CancelButtons.
To hide cancel button, provide $0.hidden(true) to the callback.
NOTE: actions attached to the cancel button (even if hidden)
will be fired when tapping the dialog backdrop.
Convenience operator to adjust the width and relational value of that
width from the built-in width (300.0). Normally, Alerts have a fixed
width with content flowing vertically, however, in case of having
elements that occupy more horizontal space it’s sometimes necessary
to force the whole alert to be wider.
Remove debug label.
Assign “alignment” to the queried stack view(s).
This affects the alignment of the arranged subviews
perpendicular to the stack view’s axis.
The view(s) flexible remainder area(s) expressed via
a closure containing the UI description of that area.
The parent used to add hierarchy into (aka $0) is
a RemainderView (UIView). Example:
AbstractMutator represents the primary interface to mutate
views, layers, guides and nodes. It is conformed by two wrappers:
Mutator and AutoLayout, handling FreeLayout-based (stateless)
mutations and AutoLayout-based (stateful) mutations, respectively,
using a single consistent API (guaranteed by this protocol).
NOTE: This wraps purely
API - never
API.
Move constraints on the queried views out of the containing super views
so that become hidden (in relation to their super views), effectively supporting
a “drawer” slide in/out effect. (animation not included)
This method also stores the original position. Use slideIn(:) to restore
to this position.
NOTE: with this method it’s recommended to call v_deinit() in the view controller’s deinit()
in order to remove any stored view states.
Attach an action that will be fired on item dismissal.
Create a new item based on reducing queried items (starting from
a seed item) and return a new Query with that item.
See also several variations of “empty()” to use as the initial item.
Get the parent Guide(s) of the current guide(s).
Treat these views upcast to their most general type, UIView.
Export this query of Guide(s) to their owning view(s).
Present the queried Presentable item(s)
with a provided data model (applied to
all item(s)) and optional duration, delay or
completion handler that the “present()”
implementation can choose to work with.
Completion handler is passed a query
of each item to take action on.
Constrain the item(s) on a specific attribute
using the AutoConstraint DSL from within a closure,
constraining the item(s) to the item’s parent
or the query reference.
All C3 wrappers are DebugConfigurable.
Turn on console debugging.
Assign “distribution” to the queried stack view(s).
This affects the distribution of the arranged views
along the stack view’s axis.
Present the queried Presentable item(s)
with optional duration, delay or
completion handler that the “present()”
implementation can choose to work with.
Completion handler is passed a query
of each item to take action on.
Iterate the rows in the current grid(s) with an arbitrary

to a closure. Number of rows created == length of data array.
Use the closure to create the hierarchy within the quadrant.
Data type can correspond to ConstructibleWithData if desired
so that items can be created in the closure using the data.
Optionally iterate rows
Reveal any BackgroundView on this Alert
with an optional theme to apply to the background.
See also “background()” (w/closure)
to reveal the background and modify it.
Iterate the columns in the current grid(s) with an arbitrary
data array, passing the data item and column (i.e. quadrant/guide)
to a closure. Number of columns created == length of data array.
Use the closure to create the hierarchy within the quadrant.
Data type can correspond to ConstructibleWithData if desired
so that items can be created in the closure using the data.
Optionally iterate columns
Respects layout direction, unless specified to

Provide a non-optional data model to be
used in presentation.
Completion handler is passed a query
of each item to take action on.
Create new items using a trailing closure.
These (child) items can be added to the parent item(s).
Update a single item with a related model object
either initially or whenever the model changes.
To apply a single data model to multiple items
use the specialized update(withOne:) method.
Optionally provide whether the visual appearance
should be updated always, conditionally or never.
Assign the “margins” of the queried stack view(s).
This causes the stack view to lay out its arranged views
relative to the provided layout margins.
Using the queried items, apply a transform to each creating
a query of new items. Transform may return nil to skip item.
If items do not yet exist in the item hierarchy “attach()”
can be used to add them.
Create new views, layers or guides using a trailing closure.
These (child) items can be added to the (parent)
guide(s) of the current query via in($0).
The return type will be UIView (child views of the parent guides).
Follow this call by further mutations applicable to the new guides.
Alternatively, to control the return type, use the generic method.
Turn off visual and console debugging.
If you want to isolate the console debugging by
focussing on a limited set of operators in the chain
(i.e. so as not to overwhelm the console) but
to have visual debugging, then use the
operator that takes a closure and wrap the operators
in the closure. This will isolate the console output to
the enclosed operators
preserve visual debugging.
Assign “spacing” to the queried stack view(s).
This affects the distance in points between the adjacent
edges of the stack view’s arranged views.
The protocol composition that views, layers, guides and nodes
conform to on all generic wrappers, such as Query, Mutator and others.
Iterate all the columns in the current grid(s) passing the
index (+ position) and the column (quadrant) to the provided
closure within which you can create the hierarchy.
Optionally iterate columns

and resume at that point. Indices will remain consecutive

This specialized method allows you to provide the type and
optional id of the top-level items you created in the
closure and have these returned as a new query of those
top-level items (of the specified type/id).
Add a button to the inner button stack with optional
index value within that stack. If index is nil it
will append button after last button. If index is
out of bounds an exception will be thrown.
Collapse constraints on the queried views for the provided attributes.
This just sets the constant to 0.0 for the provided attributes.
This method stores the original constant value which supports
calling “expand()” to restore those values.
NOTE: with this method it’s recommended to call v_deinit() in the view controller’s deinit()
in order to remove any stored view states.
Add a debug overlay or grid overlay.
See also “debug” operator which does the same.
Optionally provide overlay/grid color or for
non-grid types an overlay title.
Debug colors use brightness tinting so should
generally be dark or light (depending on your
needs). See also ColorDerivable “lighter”
or “darker” to adjust color if necessary.
Modify the Dialog stack view for this Alert via trailing closure.
Treat the current query as a subtype – for example to get
specialized functionality that would not otherwise be exposed
to a more general type.
Beware: this will remove items where the type cannot be succesfully
cast. e.g. Query
containing 2 views, a UIView and a UIButton
using treat(as:UIControl.self) will “lose” the UIView (which is
a UIControl) and return 1 view, the UIButton (which
a UIControl).
Query from the current items (with options) using a closure.
Returns empty if current query has no items.
Example: myAutoLayout.with(.nonrecursive) { $0.buttons }
NOTE: the query returned from the closure must contain
compatible AutoLayout types, including UIView and Guide
For non-view based queries (layers, guides, nodes)
get the containing (or owning) view(s), of a specified type.
Traverse this query’s items and another query’s items in
parallel, returning a new query with items returned from zipper.
Keeps original base.
The original query of items

Perform new item creations on parent item(s) in
a closure if parent item(s) (or least the first
parent item) have not yet been displayed on the screen.
Regardless, this method returns new items just created
or already existing.
Modify the dialog’s title text and other DisplayText attributes.
If this item is an “Alert”, be sure to pass the application
Theme when attaching dialog via “in(with:theme)” so that the
title will obtain the correct theme.
It’s not necessary to size this title to fit, as autolayout
will do that for you.
If this method is not used the title will be hidden but continue
to occupy the space. To remove the title completely set it’s height
to 0.0, e.g.: title { $0.layout.height(0.0} }
Query the current views/guides for constraint(s) of a given
attribute and optional priority and pass that constraint to
a closure to be modified.
Optionally, specify
to find constraints where
the current items match the second item (
) in the
constraint or either items (
TIP: for most autolayout needs use the AutoLayout operators such
as size, width, height, center, pin, etc, which set initial
constraint(s), resolve conflicts, update constant/priority
(on existing) and other functionality.
Reserve this method for advanced layout.
Save the current AutoLayout to a variable,
the current items onto that external variable (i.e. as
opposed to just replacing the external variable). This
is useful in loops where it’s necessary to gather results
or when it’s necessary to perform an action on multiple items.
Supports saving diverse subtypes of a common type.
e.g. var views = AL
.empty() - UIView
..   CircleView().in($0)….accumulate(&views) - subtype
IMPORTANT: Use “var” for empty wrapper else this will not work.
The base of the last accumulated query becomes the base
of the saved query (which in context is usually the same).
Param “preserveOrder” ensures new items are appended
to the end of the current query, thus maintaining order
– this is the default behavior.
Create new views, layers or guides using a trailing closure.
These (child) items can be added to the (parent)
guide(s) of the current query via in($0).
The return type will be Guide (child guides of the parent guide).
Follow this call by further mutations applicable to the new guides.
Alternatively, to control the return type, use the generic method.
Perform mutations with options or parameters within
a closure without affecting the outer autolayout.
Treat the current query’s base as some other type/subtype.
Beware: this may remove the base altogether if the type
cannot be successfully cast.
Modify the inner button stack view for this Alert
via trailing closure. To remove all buttons set
height to 0.0, e.g. buttonStack { $0.layout.height(0.0) }
Iterate the rows in the current grid(s) with an arbitrary
data array, passing the data item and row (i.e. quadrant/guide)
to a closure. Number of rows created == length of data array.
Use the closure to create the hierarchy within the quadrant.
Data type can correspond to ConstructibleWithData if desired
so that items can be created in the closure using the data.
Optionally iterate rows
This specialized method allows you to provide the type and
optional id of the top-level items you created in the
closure and have these returned as a new query of those
top-level items (of the specified type/id).
Wrap part of the chain in debug (with options) ensuring that
unneeded console output is avoided for the rest of the chain.
Regardless, visual debugging enabled here will remain enabled.
Iterate all the cells in the current grid(s) passing
an index (+ cell position) and the cell (quadrant)
to the closure within which you can create the hierarchy.
Optional sort directions (8 in total) support diverse
flow progressions, for example
to progress
down the cells of the first column, and then to the next
column, etc. Default is
Respects layout direction, unless specified to

(or
) from the closure to

to skip

and resume at that point. Indices will remain consecutive

PERFORMANCE: Grids with a large number of cells may cause
performance issues due to the number of guides/constraints involved.
Make sure to performance test (e.g. via Instruments) when using this API.
Traverse the queried views/guides and activate all constraints
that correspond to the provided attributes and optional priority.

Traverse this query’s items and an arbitrary array of
things in parrallel with a trailing closure that is
passed an item and a thing. The resulting query length
will be the shorter of the two.
Turn on visual and console debugging with
existing debug configuration.
Modify the dialog’s details text and other DisplayText attributes.
If this item is an “Alert”, be sure to pass the application
Theme when attaching dialog via “in(with:theme)” so that the
text will obtain the correct theme.
It’s not necessary to size this text to fit, as autolayout
will do that for you.
If this method is not used the text will be hidden but continue
to occupy the space. To remove the text completely set it’s height
to 0.0, e.g.: text { $0.layout.height(0.0} }
Modify the BackgroundView via trailing closure.
For Alerts the background is hidden by default.
Calling this method will cause the background
to be revealed. See also “addBackground(with:Theme)”
to just reveal the background.
Background exists at the back of the dialog stack view.
Create new views, layers or guides using a trailing closure.
These (child) items can be added to the (parent)
guide(s) of the current query via in($0).
The return type will be CALayer (child layers of the parent guides owning views).
Follow this call by further mutations applicable to the new layers.
Alternatively, to control the return type, use the generic method.
The guide(s) flexible remainder area(s) expressed via
a closure containing the UI description of that area.
The parent used to add hierarchy into (aka $0) is
a RemainderGuide (UILayoutGuide). Example:
Select items of a certain type
alias to treat(as)

to a closure. Number of cells created == length of data array.
Use the closure to create the hierarchy within the quadrant.
Data type can correspond to ConstructibleWithData if desired

This specialized method allows you to provide the type and
optional id of the top-level items you created in the
closure and have these returned as a new query of those
top-level items (of the specified type/id).
PERFORMANCE: Grids with a large number of cells may cause
performance issues due to the number of guides/constraints involved.
Make sure to performance test (e.g. via Instruments) when using this API.
Modify and provide action for any button in this Alert
referencing the index within the arranged subviews of
the stackview.
It’s not necessary to size text to fit, as autolayout
will do that for you.
To hide the button, provide $0.hidden(true) to the callback.
Enter debug mode with
This provides both visual typographic debugging
and console debugging.
See debugTypographic() for more options.
Export this query of Guide(s) to their guide layer(s).
Expand constraints on the queried views for the provided attributes.
This restores the constant to the original constant prior to
running “collapse()”. As a result of that, this method will not
work as expected if collapse() has not been fired in the current memory stack.
Given a query of items apply a flatMap transform that
returns arrays of items that become combined into
a single array or Query of items.
Add debug rulers to queried item(s)
with optional style (grid, coordinates
or centers) and shade (dark or light).
Use “flip” to flip one or both axes.
Randomly iterate all the cells in the current grid(s),
passing the index (+ position) and random cell (i.e. quadrant/guide)
to the closure in order to create the hierarchy within
that cell. The indexes will be provided to the closure in
strict consecutive order, so you can use that to determine
the data model for that content.
Return
from closure to stop iteration.
Given a query of DefinableArea(s) refit them back
to their configured area definitions.
Move constraints on the queried views back in to the containing super views
so that they are restored to their original position (in relation to their super
views), effectively supporting a “drawer” slide in/out effect. (animation not included).
This method restores the original position that was stored in slideOut.
Turn on visual and console debugging.
See console to turn on only console debugging.
AbstractTypographicalMutator provides additional
API that is specific to typographic mutations,
supported by both wrappers, Mutator and AutoLayout.
Update the item(s) with the related model object
either initially or whenever the model changes.
Provided model object is applied to all items.
If the intention is to apply a single model object
to a single item, use the regular update(with:)
method instead.
To apply multiple models in parallel to multiple items
use the update(with:) method which takes an array.
Optionally provide whether the visual appearance
should be updated always, conditionally or never.
